explanation: The report is correct. The for loop is declared as for (i = 0; i < len; ++i) so i is the loop counter, but the loop body modifies i several times (examples: if (++i < len) { ... }, the second if (++i < len) and the ++i in the else branch). MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 requires that the loop counter shall not be modified in the for-loop body (the only permitted modification of the loop counter is the third clause of the for statement). Therefore the code violates Rule 14.2. (Resolution options: rewrite the logic to avoid modifying i inside the body—e.g. use a while loop, a separate inner index, or adjust the loop increment to match the body’s progress.)
